HVAC/R Eﬃciency Report
Purpose of Energy Eﬃciency Study
The purpose of this study is to verify the industry wide problem of efficiency loss in HVAC/R as projected by 
ASHRAE research and to quantify the amount of money wasted due to this loss. Many industry leading 
organizations including ASHRAE project that all HVAC/R units degrade in capacity and efficiency as they age. 
Thermal degradation is caused by a phenomenon that is present in all HVAC/R equipment that operates as a 
vapor compression cycle associated with refrigerant and compressor lubricant. This thermal degradation is well 
documented by the HVAC/R industry and the original equipment manufacturers (OEM’s). Thermal 
degradation prevents units from operating at the original design efficiency, which leads to excessive run-times 
and additional kWh consumption.
The chiller in this study is representative of a great majority of the portfolio of equipment operated by Global Telecom Equipment Manufacturer. 
If thermal degradation is present in this chiller it is present in the entire inventory of equipment. Energy waste 
can be calculated based on this equipment (portfolio representation) and then accurately extrapolated across 
the entire inventory of equipment.
As demonstrated in this field trial, PermaFrost NMR® restores the capacity of chiller systems lost over time due 
to fouling of the heat exchange surfaces in both the evaporator and condenser barrels. This restoration of 
capacity will manifest itself in any or all of the following ways:
• Ability of the chiller to better satisfy fluctuating building loads or lower room temps
• Produce additional redundancy at no extra cost or interruption to facility operations 
• Improve chiller efficiency, lowering cost to produce each ton of cooling required 
• Restore thermal efficiency, allowing chiller to achieve CW set point at lower load
• Improve chiller performance and extending equipment life by 15%+ 
• Reduce overall energy consumption and peak demand charges (KVA)

Highlights of the study:
When comparing the pilot chiller system before and eight weeks after PermaFrost NMR® was installed, below 
are some of the highlights of the study:
• When initially tested, the pilot chiller system was producing 703 tons of cooling at the given testing 
   conditions. Eight weeks after installation, the cooling capacity increased by 151 tons or 21.5% to 854 tons. 
• The overall cost to produce each ton of cooling on the pilot chiller system dropped 18.6% from .587 
   kW/ton in the baseline to .478 kW/ton eight weeks after installation. This means that for every ton of 
   cooling the pilot chiller system is asked to produce, Global Telecom Equipment Manufacturer is spending 18.6% less to do so.
• The projected annual kWh’s were reduced by 18.6% from 1,503,000 to 1,224,000.
• The Coefficient of Performance (COP) for the pilot chiller system was increased from 5.99 in the 
   baseline to 7.36 in the post which represents an increase in efficiency of 22.9%
The chiller system involved in the study is recorded as follows:
 York; Mfg date 2001; R22 Refrigerant; Nominal 1,000-ton capacity, 480 volt-3 Phase,
 Model 4KHHHBJ1, SN 035-18644-000

Methodology
The measurements used in the efficiency calculations were collected and compiled in accordance with the 
IPMVP (International Measurement and Verification Protocol) framework. The team was led by Global Telecom Equipment Manufacturer’s 
 Testing Manager, [Client Representative], P.E., was supported by Commercial Real Estate Services’s [Facility Manager], Facility Manager and Powertron Global’s Director of Engineering, [Senior Energy Engineer].  
Notes 
The chiller tested (see photo below) is one of the most efficient types of chillers York manufactured at that point in time.  
Both the baseline and post measurement s were taken with outside air temperatures of 63 and 65 respectfully. The effect of 
this slight difference in temperature as well as a similar slight difference in incoming condenser water from the tower are 
both within the industry-accepted margin of error and thereby considered insignificant in terms of overall results.  
Global Telecom Equipment Manufacturer’s repeatable management of the chiller 
plant during the trial provided more than an 
adequate heat load on the facility to ensure the 
chiller would remain running during the actual 
data collection period. 
The boundary of the testing was the chiller and 
nothing else; therefore confidence in the accuracy 
of the performance calculations is very high.

4
Energy Conservation Method (ECM)
The content detailed in this report will first demonstrate the ability of the pilot chiller to perform prior to the 
ECM being installed, as well as illustrate the amount of thermal degradation 
within the heat exchangers.
The following report produces the utilization of the IPMVP as the M&V plan. 
The results were formulated by entering the data into the following thermodynamic engineering formulas:
 
• kW = (Volts * Amps * Power Factor * Sq root of 3)/1000 (for 3-Phase) 
 
• kW/Ton = kW / Actual Tonnage 
 
• Coefficient of Performance (COP) = (12 / kW per ton /3.412)
 
• Cooling Tons per Hr = (Evaporator GPM * 8.34 * 60 * CW Delta T) / 12,000 BTU 
 
• Refrigerant Approach = CW Supply Temp – Saturated Evaporator Temp (CH) 
Notes 
Following a diagnostic examination of the pilot equipment to determine the operational condition of the systems was 
satisfactory, Baseline M&V data was collected and recorded by the M&V team. 600+ hours after installation of the ECM, 
the M&V team returned on a very similar weather day to the Baseline to take Post M&V measurements in the identical 
fashion as in the Baseline. The delta of these measurements and associated calculations show the amount of capacity 
restored.
The following IPMVP data points were recorded on 5 May 2014 using recently calibrated devices by NIST (National 
Institutes of Standards and Technology) to insure measurement accuracy. The chiller was then treated with PermaFrost 
NMR® on the same day and allowed to run at greater than 70% load until 26 June 2014 to ensure the patented surface 
science nanotechnology had ample time to seat into all the metal surfaces of the heat exchangers. All measurements were 
taken at 70% load and at similar outdoor air temperatures. 
The York chiller treated has a nominal capacity of 1,000 tons at 100% load and 2,400 gallons per minute (GPM) flow 
through the evaporator.  The chiller used in this pilot was tested at 70% load with a GPM of 2,675. This scenario creates a 
type of false-positive tonnage amount but since normal operations were not to be changed for the pilot, the emphasis here is 
on the delta between baseline and post.

Chiller Eﬃciency Study Results 
Global Telecom Equipment Manufacturer has the problem of thermal degradation in its chillers. The lower operating tonnage and COP ratings 
measured on site in the baseline were in line with the ASHRAE loss of performance and cost to operate 
numbers. The degraded equipment performance was costing Global Telecom Equipment Manufacturer significant money and wasting energy. 
The chiller was shown in the baseline to be using significantly more kWh to operate than it used when it was 
new. 
The performance results include the measured efficiency and tonnage of the chiller in the baseline and post 
testing periods demonstrating the negative impact thermal degradation had on the chiller and how PermaFrost 
NMR® was able to reverse that and restore capacity.

7
Energy Consumption & Financial Metrics
The following are the final calculated average performance measurements before and after PermaFrost NMR® 
was installed on the pilot chiller system. 
Average Baseline Energy Consumption
Baseline Capacity:  703 tons
Adjusted kW Baseline:  .587 kW/ton * 854 tons = 501 kW
Adjusted Baseline kWh:  501 kW * 3,000 Annual Operating Hours = 1,503,000 kWh
Revised Cost to Run Baseline: 1,503,000 kWh * $.12 = $180,360
Avgerage Post Energy Consumption
kW Post:  .478 kW/ton * 854 tons = 408 kW
Annual kWh Post:  408 kW * 3,000 hours = 1,224,000 kWh
Annual Cost Post:  1,224,000 kWh * $.12 cents = $146,880
Average Savings per Year Per System
Avoided Energy Cost (savings) Per Year:  $180,360 - $146,880 = $33,480
Estimated Energy Savings per Month: $33,480 / 12 = $2,790
Return on Investment
Cost of PermaFrost NMR® installed in the pilot chiller system: $29,500
Estimated ROI for Global Telecom Equipment Manufacturer when treating the pilot chiller system: $29,500 / $2,790 = ~10.6 mos
Annual Internal Rate of Return = 113%
Return on Investment Over 5 Years = 567%
Explanation of Regression Analysis
To obtain a true avoided energy cost and subsequent payback period for Global Telecom Equipment Manufacturer for implementing the PermaFrost NMR® ECM, 
a detailed Regression Analysis is used to calculate the true energy savings resulting from the improvement in both capacity and 
efficiency utilizing data collected during the pilot study. Together these improvements reduce the annual kWh expended annually 
in the future. The ROI comes from determining what the cost to run the chiller system was when operating at the original energy 
profile to produce the newly restored amount of available capacity and then subtracting the revised cost to run the chiller system 
at the same restored capacity after PermaFrost NMR® was installed. This regression analysis is the most widely accepted method 
of accounting for the reduced number of hours and/or load % at which the chiller system will now operate due to the restored 
performance profile. This restored performance profile allows the chiller system to satisfy the chilled water set points with 
increased efficiency resulting in reduced compressor demand loading.
